entities.description: location in city of Ljubljana, probably named after first settlers, heathens

events.description: He was born in Ljubljana, then part of the Austro-Hungarian empire.
He died in Ljubljana.
Ernest Adamič was attending the Eight-class II. City Boy's Folk School (Osemrazredna II. mestna deška ljudska šola) in Ljubljana.
He befriended Tone Seliškar.
During World War I (1914-18), he served in the Gebirgschützenregiment (Mountain Rifle Regiment No. 2), surviving the 9th, 10th and 11th Italian offensive
After his return, he attended a special course at the teachers' college and graduated in 1919.
He first taught at the (old) boys' school in Novo mesto
Ernest Adamič married Marija Repič and became son-in-law to Alojzij Repič, an academic sculptor.
His next postings were in Škocjan near Turjak (with his wife Marija) and Tomišelj pod Krimom

label.default: Working and directing theater plays in Zagorje

events.description: He worked in Zagorje as an education worker and theater director.
In 1941, together with other teachers from Zagorje, he lost his job and took a temporary job as a "shihtenšrajber" (probably a shift census taker) at the Dukič company in Toplice near Zagorje

label.default: Writing in different publications and under different names

events.description: The school in Zagorje was mostly attended by the children of miners, and it was in this proletarian environment that Adamič began to write for the newspaper Jutro under the pseudonym Netko. He also published under the pseudonyms AMI (the middle three letters of his surname), Razorčev (the name of his mother's farm) and Arnest a.e. and a.a. At the same time, he wrote youth stories for Naš rod (after the war for the magazines Pionir and Ciciban) and as a publicist he published in Slovenske narod, Učiteljski tovariš, Mladina and Žika, and after the war in Ljudska pravica, Tovariš, Filmu ...).

At first these were short impressions from the Zagorje valley, which eventually developed into writing feuilletons with more serious aspirations (the editor of Zvonček, Pavle Karlin, was the first to publish a short story by Adamić, Deček iz sirotišnice (The Boy from the Orphanage).
When he found out that they were going to be evicted, he moved with his family to Ljubljana
Worked as a secretary at the Red Cross, in charge of confidential reports on the orders of the Red Cross secretary Drago Zupančič.

label.default: Worked at Fuel Office of the Chamber of Commerce, Trade and Industry

events.description: In 1943, he was given a part time job at the Fuel Office of the Chamber of Commerce, Trade and Industry.
Wrote an unpublished diary titled 240 dni okupirane Ljubljane (240 days of Occupied Ljubljana)
From 9 August 1941 onwards, he led OF meetings in the Ajdovščina area under the pseudonym Marko
On 16 May 1944, he and some others were betrayed and arrested for conspiration and taken to the Dachau concentration camp
After his arrest, he was imprisoned in the Dachau concentration camp

label.default: Worked at the Kolodvor field office

events.description: After the war, he was secretary of the Kolodvor field office in Ljubljana until November 1947

label.default: Worked at the Ministry of Trade and Supply

events.description: He took up the post of press officer at the Ministry of Trade and Supply

label.default: Worked at the Directorate of Cinematography in Ljubljana

events.description: Worked as a propagandist and publicist at the then Directorate of Cinematography in Ljubljana
Worked for Triglav film
Became a freelancer
Short film Otok galebov.
Short film Puščica nad gladino.
Short film Kraški kramarji.
Short film Štehvanje presented old Slavic customs of boys on horseback to win the affection of girls.

label.default: Short film V dolini Soče (In the Soča Valley)

events.description: Short film V dolini Soče (In the Soča Valley) was filmed as a touristic film exploring the natural history of the valley Soča.
He made a film about the Auschwitz concetration camp titled Človek postoj. In it he infused a part of his experience when he was held in Dachau.
The film Pepel, ki žge was made about the concentration campm Mauthausen, inspired by his experience when he was held in Dachau.
The feature film Dobro morje was made in 1958, based on a much revised script.
